title: Malware gang uses .NET library to generate Excel docs that bypass security checks
desc: They were still Excel documents. Just not your typical Excel files. Enough to trick some security systems, though.

title: Millions of WordPress sites are being probed & attacked with recent plugin bug
desc: An easy-to-exploit vulnerability in a popular WordPress plugin has triggered an internet-wide hacking spree.

title: CyberCX continues NZ expansion with Insomnia Security purchase
desc: Australia and New Zealand cybersecurity megamix adds first Kiwi acquisition.

title: Why both Huawei and BTS share the cyber stage with powerful nations
desc: Cyber conflict isn't about cyberwar, says The Grugq. It's about a global cyber power struggle that never ends, where even K-pop bands can influence nation states.

title: Firefox will add a new drive-by-download protection
desc: Firefox will block automatic downloads initiated from sandboxed iframes -- the technology usually used for web embeds.

title: US election: Two-thirds of typosquatted domains are non-malicious or parked sites
desc: Digital Shadows researchers analyzed 225 typosquatted domains registered using election-related terms such as Trump, Biden, Pence, and others.

title: Threema E2EE chat app to go 'fully open source' within months
desc: Threema follows in the footsteps of Signal and Wickr and opens its apps' codebase.

title: Pentagon says it plans to stick with Microsoft as JEDI cloud contract winner
desc: After many legal twists and turns, the Department of Defense says it has decided that Microsoft is the winning bidder for the $10 billion JEDI cloud contract.

title: White House publishes a cyber-security rulebook for space systems
desc: Nothing in it about protecting thermal exhaust ports, though.

title: Cisco Issues Warning Over IOS XR Zero-Day Flaw Being Targeted in the Wild
desc: Cisco has warned of an active zero-day vulnerability in its router software that's being exploited in the wild and could allow a remote, authenticated attacker to carry out memory exhaustion attacks on an affected device.

title: Maximum Lifespan of SSL/TLS Certificates is 398 Days Starting Today
desc: Starting today, the lifespan of new TLS certificates will be limited to 398 days, a little over a year, from the previous maximum certificate lifetime of 27 months (825 days).

title: New Web-Based Credit Card Stealer Uses Telegram Messenger to Exfiltrate Data
desc: Cybercriminal groups are constantly evolving to find new ways to pilfer financial information, and the latest trick in their arsenal is to leverage the messaging app Telegram to their benefit.

title: Cisco Jabber Bug Could Let Hackers Target Windows Systems Remotely
desc: Networking equipment maker Cisco has released a new version of its Jabber video conferencing and messaging app for Windows that includes patches for multiple vulnerabilities—which, if exploited, could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code.

title: (Live) Webinar – XDR and Beyond with Autonomous Breach Protection
desc: Anyone paying attention to the cybersecurity technology market has heard the term XDR - Extended Detection and Response.   XDR is a new technology approach that combines multiple protection technologies into a single platform.

title: Evilnum hackers targeting financial firms with a new Python-based RAT
desc: An adversary known for targeting the fintech sector at least since 2018 has switched up its tactics to include a new Python-based remote access Trojan (RAT) that can steal passwords, documents, browser cookies, email credentials, and other sensitive information.

title: Google Play apps promised free shoes, but users got ad fraud malware instead
desc: White Ops discovers a collection of Android apps that installed a hidden browser to load ad-heavy pages and commit ad fraud.

title: Chinese researcher charged with destroying evidence relating to illegal transfer of US tech
desc: If convicted, the researcher could face up to 20 years of prison time.

title: TikTok's potential sale could be impacted by China's updated export rules: Report
desc: The new export rules could potentially allow China to block the sale of TikTok to a US company.

title: Microsoft and Walmart are teaming on a potential TikTok takeover deal
desc: Microsoft is still in the TikTok bidding, with Amazon adversary Walmart by its side.

title: Iranian hackers impersonate journalists to set up WhatsApp calls and gain victims' trust
desc: Iranian hackers impersonated journalists from German TV Deutsche Welle and Israeli magazine Jewish Journal, and the Wall Street Journal in earlier attacks this year.

title: Facebook sues maker of advertising SDK for refusing to participate in audit
desc: Facebook also sued the operator of a website selling Instagram followers, likes, and comments.

title: US sues to recover cryptocurrency funds stolen by North Korean hackers
desc: US officials are going after 280 BTC and ETH accounts storing funds North Korean hackers stole from two cryptocurrency exchanges.

title: New Zealand Stock Exchange suffers day four disruption following DDoS attacks
desc: The NZX was hoping to open on Friday but says it's experiencing connectivity issues resembling attacks from earlier in the week.

title: Elon Musk confirms Russian hacking plot targeted Tesla factory
desc: A Russian hacker tried to recruit a Tesla employee working for the company's factory in Sparks, Nevada.

title: Academics bypass PINs for Visa contactless payments
desc: Researchers: "In other words, the PIN is useless in Visa contactless transactions.

title: Former engineer pleads guilty to Cisco network damage, causing Webex Teams account chaos
desc: The engineer was responsible for damage that cost Cisco $2.4 million to rectify.

title: Best home security systems in 2020: Ring, Nest, SimpliSafe, Abode, and more
desc: ZDNet has brought together the best options on the market from DIY kits to full smart home setups.

title: Surprise! Even Google's engineers don't understand its privacy controls
desc: From their very inception, tech companies haven't been keen on privacy. They've also not been keen on making privacy controls easy. As court documents just revealed.

title: It’s never the data breach -- it’s always the cover-up
desc: The felony charges levied against former Uber CSO paints him as actively masterminding and executing a plan to cover up a major data breach. This serves as a reminder that CSOs and CISOs must consider how decisions made in the moment can be interpreted, construed, or proven to be criminal after the fact.

title: Malicious npm package caught trying to steal sensitive Discord and browser files
desc: Malicious code was hidden inside a JavaScript library for working with the "Fall Guys: Ultimate Knockout" game API.

title: Iranian Hackers Pose as Journalists to Trick Victims Into Installing Malware
desc: An Iranian cyberespionage group known for targeting government, defense technology, military, and diplomacy sectors is now impersonating journalists to approach targets via LinkedIn and WhatsApp and infect their devices with malware.

title: QakBot Banking Trojan Returned With New Sneaky Tricks to Steal Your Money
desc: A notorious banking trojan aimed at stealing bank account credentials and other financial information has now come back with new tricks up its sleeve to target government, military, and manufacturing sectors in the US and Europe, according to new research.

title: Australia Post parcel portal offline following 'technical' issue
desc: The parcel delivery business of the government-owned entity was down, with Australia Post apologising for any inconvenience.

title: Your email threads are now being hijacked by the QBot Trojan
desc: Operators have changed their tactics in the quest for data theft.

title: Popular iOS SDK Accused of Spying on Billions of Users and Committing Ad Fraud
desc: A popular iOS software development kit (SDK) used by over 1,200 apps—with a total of more than a billion mobile users—is said to contain malicious code with the goal of perpetrating mobile ad-click fraud and capturing sensitive information.

title: APT Hackers Exploit Autodesk 3ds Max Software for Industrial Espionage
desc: It's one thing for APT groups to conduct cyber espionage to meet their own financial objectives. But it's an entirely different matter when they are used as "hackers for hire" by competing private companies to make away with confidential information.

title: Russian Arrested After Offering $1 Million to U.S. Company Employee for Planting Malware
desc: Hackers always find a way in, even if there's no software vulnerability to exploit.

title: Two members of movie piracy group 'Sparks' arrested in Cyprus and the US
desc: Investigators said the group posed as real-world DVD/Blu-Ray retailers to obtain and leak unreleased movies and TV shows.

title: A quarter of the Alexa Top 10K websites are using browser fingerprinting scripts
desc: Academics also discover many new previously unreported JavaScript APIs that are currently being used to fingerprint users.

title: Twitter takes down 'Dracula' botnet pushing pro-Chinese propaganda
desc: Botnet was estimated at around 3,000 bots, before accounts were suspended or restricted last week.

title: Data#3 says it has been hit by a non-notifiable cyber incident
desc: Company has made contact with 28 of its impacted customers and says its ongoing operations are fine.

title: DDoS extortionists target NZX, Moneygram, Braintree, and other financial services
desc: One of the victims, the New Zealand stock exchange (NZX), has halted trading for the third day in a row following the attacks.

title: Do intelligence agencies need restructuring for the digital disinformation age?
desc: The focus needs to change and more oversight is needed, but digital skulduggery won't replace the need for human spies.

title: Mercenary hacker group targets companies with 3Ds Max malware
desc: Hacker-for-hire group uses a malicious 3Ds Max plugin to infect companies with malware and steal proprietary information.

title: APT Hackers Exploit Autodesk 3D Max Software for Industrial Espionage
desc: It's one thing for APT groups to conduct cyber espionage to meet their own financial objectives. But it's an entirely different matter when they are used as "hackers for hire" by competing private companies to make away with confidential information.

title: Google Researcher Reported 3 Flaws in Apache Web Server Software
desc: If your web-server runs on Apache, you should immediately install the latest available version of the server application to prevent hackers from taking unauthorized control over it.

title: Get Lifetime Access to 1000+ Premium Online Training Courses for Just $59
desc: "In today's knowledge economy, continual learning is an imperative." — Those words from Aytekin Tank, the founder of JotForm, are particularly important for anyone working in IT or development.

title: Popular iOS SDK Caught Spying on Billions of Users and Committing Ad Fraud
desc: A popular iOS software development kit (SDK) used by over 1,200 apps—with a total of more than a billion mobile users—is said to contain malicious code with the goal of perpetrating mobile ad-click fraud and capturing sensitive information.

title: Security researcher discloses Safari bug after Apple delays patch
desc: Safari bug could be abused to leak or steal files from users' devices.

title: Global pandemic opening up can of security worms
desc: Caught by the sudden onslaught of COVID-19, most businesses lacked or had inadequate security systems in place to support remote work and now have to deal with a new reality that includes a much wider attack surface and less secured user devices.

title: Lazarus group strikes cryptocurrency firm through LinkedIn job adverts
desc: Updated: A system administrator proved to be the weak link, opening the door for Lazarus to attack.

title: Microsoft: This Office 365 feature update lets you open attachments without fear of malware
desc: Microsoft releases public preview of Application Guard for Office.

title: Browser-based cryptojacking sees sudden spike in activity in Q2 2020
desc: However, there's nothing to worry about. Browser-based cryptojacking is not making a comeback.

title: No, no one has secretly installed a COVID-19 tracker onto your smartphone
desc: Social media is awash with claims that Google or Apple has secretly installed COVID-19 trackers onto user's iPhones and Android smartphones.

title: Conti (Ryuk) joins the ranks of ransomware gangs operating data leak sites
desc: More and more ransomware gangs are now operating sites where they leak sensitive data from victims who refuse to pay the ransom demand.

title: FBI informant provides a glimpse into the inner workings of tech support scams
desc: Court documents expose how tech support scammers operate.

title: Russian arrested for trying to recruit an insider and hack a Nevada company
desc: A Russian national traveled to the US to recruit and convince an employee of a Nevada company to install malware on the company's network.

title: NSW pledges AU$60m to create cyber 'army'
desc: As part of the New South Wales government's AU$240 million commitment to all things cyber.

title: Brute-force cyberattacks on the rise in Brazil
desc: The widespread adoption of remote working is the main driver behind the increase, according to a new report.

title: Report claims a popular iOS SDK is stealing click revenue from other ad networks
desc: The suspicious iOS SDK is used by more than 1,200 apps, with 300 million downloads/month.

title: Palo Alto Networks to acquire incident response firm Crypsis Group for $265M
desc: Meanwhile, the cybersecurity firm posted better-than-expected Q4 results, thanks in part to work-from-home tailwinds.

title: Enough with the Linux security FUD
desc: Every few weeks, another security story appears saying how insecure Linux is. There's only one problem with most of them: They're fake news. The real problem is incompetent system administrators.

title: Security researcher discloses Safari bug after Apple's delays patch
desc: Safari bug could be abused to leak or steal files from users' devices.

title: Group of unskilled Iranian hackers behind recent attacks with Dharma ransomware
desc: Security firm Group-IB says the hackers have been targeting companies in Russia, Japan, China, and India.

title: Blockchain could help colleges like ASU provide better, more secure online education
desc: Arizona State University believes blockchain will be key to helping it deliver online education to over 100,000+ students by 2025.

title: Chromium DNS hijacking detection accused of being around half of all root queries
desc: A trio of random domain probes sent from the browser account for half of all DNS queries that escalate up to the root servers.

title: Top exploits used by ransomware gangs are VPN bugs, but RDP still reigns supreme
desc: While some ransomware groups have heavily targeted Citrix and Pulse Secure VPNs to breach corporate networks in H1 2020, most ransomware attacks take place because of compromised RDP endpoints.

title: TikTok to sue US government over ban
desc: Chinese mobile app maker has confirmed plans to "challenge" the Trump administration's August 6 executive order "through the judiciary system", though, any lawsuit will not stop its forced sale in the US market.

title: Police launch drones to make sure you're wearing a mask
desc: As Covid continues to plague, will the police be tempted to take technological liberties? In Australia, they're trying.

title: A Google Drive 'Feature' Could Let Attackers Trick You Into Installing Malware
desc: An unpatched security weakness in Google Drive could be exploited by malware attackers to distribute malicious files disguised as legitimate documents or images, enabling bad actors to perform spear-phishing attacks comparatively with a high success rate.

title: Few Singaporeans able to identify all phishing email: survey
desc: Some 66% of consumers in Singapore are aware of phishing attacks, but just 4% can correctly identify all phishing email in an online survey conducted for Cyber Security of Singapore.

title: Programming language Rust: Mozilla job cuts have hit us badly but here's how we'll survive
desc: No existential threat to the Rust programming language, despite major layoffs at its main sponsor, Mozilla.

title: FBI and CISA warn of major wave of vishing attacks targeting teleworkers
desc: Hackers are calling employees working from home and tricking them into accessing phishing pages for corporate domains.

title: Before taking that DNA test: Six things you need to know
desc: As DNA testing becomes more common, more and more of us are spitting saliva. But what exactly is a DNA test? How does it work? What are the implications? We try to answer these questions here.

title: Free photos, graphics site Freepik discloses data breach impacting 8.3m users
desc: Freepik is one of the most popular websites on the internet, currently ranked #97 on the Alexa Top 100 sites list.

title: Facebook tightens screws on QAnon and US militia groups
desc: Social network says it has booted 790 QAnon groups and 980 groups related to US militias, which Facebook said includes some antifa.

title: HealthEngine fined for sharing patient data without consent and skewing its reviews
desc: Federal Court orders the company pay AU$2.9 million in penalties.

title: Australia's CyberCX launches New Zealand chapter
desc: Touting an investment of over NZ$30 million into the Kiwi cyber market.

title: Working from home causes surge in security breaches, staff 'oblivious' to best practices
desc: The coronavirus pandemic is thought to be at the heart of a rise in security incidents this year.

title: The best password managers for business: 1Password, Keeper, LastPass, and more
desc: Everyone needs a password manager. It's the only way to maintain unique, hard-to-guess credentials for every secure site you and your team access daily.

title: Cisco bug warning: Critical static password flaw in network appliances needs patching
desc: Cisco urges users to install updates for a critical flaw and another bug that lets attackers halt surveillance cameras.

title: Bug bounty platform ZDI awarded $25m to researchers over the past 15 years
desc: Bug bounty platform pioneer Zero-Day Initiative (ZDI) is celebrating its 15-year-old birthday this year.

title: Transparent Tribe APT targets government, military by infecting USB devices
desc: The hacking group is focused on campaigns in India and Afghanistan.

title: Google fixes major Gmail bug seven hours after exploit details go public
desc: Attackers could have sent spoofed emails mimicking any Gmail or G Suite customer.

title: ATM makers Diebold and NCR deploy fixes for 'deposit forgery' attacks
desc: ATMs from the two companies had bugs that could have allowed card fraudsters to modify the amount of money they deposited on their card, and then abuse the new account balance for illegal cash withdrawals.

title: Former Uber CSO charged for 2016 hack cover-up
desc: DOJ officials say former Uber CSO Joe Sullivan lied to management about the security breach and paid hush money to the hackers.

title: Instacart discloses security incident caused by two contractors
desc: Instacart says two employees at a third-party support vendor accessed "more shopper profiles than was necessary.

title: University of Utah pays $457,000 to ransomware gang
desc: University officials restored from backups, but they had to pay the ransomware gang to prevent them from leaking student data.

title: ASIC takes former ANZ-owned RI Advice to court over inadequate cybersecurity
desc: Previously owned by ANZ Bank, RI Advice Group has been hauled to court by the financial services watchdog over failure to have adequate cybersecurity systems in place.

title: Modernisation and upping cyber compliance on the agenda for Geoscience Australia
desc: The government agency plans to make security upgrades that are in line with the Essential Eight and keep digital transformation a priority.

title: A New Fileless P2P Botnet Malware Targeting SSH Servers Worldwide
desc: Cybersecurity researchers today took the wraps off a sophisticated, multi-functional peer-to-peer (P2P) botnet written in Golang that has been actively targeting SSH servers since January 2020.

title: XDR: The Next Level of Prevention, Detection and Response [New Guide]
desc: One new security technology we keep hearing about is Extended Detection and Response (XDR).

title: Experts Reported Security Bug in IBM's Db2 Data Management Software
desc: Cybersecurity researchers today disclosed details of a memory vulnerability in IBM's Db2 family of data management products that could potentially allow a local attacker to access sensitive data and even cause a denial of service attacks.   The flaw ( CVE-2020-4414 ), which impacts IBM Db2 V9.

title: Microsoft Issues Emergency Security Updates for Windows 8.1 and Server 2012 R2
desc: Microsoft has issued an emergency out-of-band software update for Windows 8.1, Windows RT 8.1, and Windows Server 2012 R2 systems to patch two new recently disclosed security vulnerabilities.

title: Experian South Africa Suffers Data Breach Affecting Millions; Attacker Identified
desc: The South African arm of one of the world's largest credit check companies Experian yesterday announced  a data breach incident that exposed personal information of millions of its customers.

title: Hackers Target Defense Contractors' Employees By Posing as Recruiters
desc: The United States Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has published a new report  warning companies about a new in-the-wild malware that North Korean hackers are reportedly using to spy on key employees at government contracting companies.

title: Former Uber Security Chief Charged Over Covering Up 2016 Data Breach
desc: The federal prosecutors in the United States have charged Uber's former chief security officer,  Joe Sullivan , for covering up a massive data breach  that the ride-hailing company suffered in 2016.   According to the press release published  by the U.S.

title: Crypto-mining worm steals AWS credentials
desc: TeamTNT has become the first crypto-minining botnet to include a feature that scans and steal AWS credentials.

title: Ukraine arrests gang who ran 20 crypto-exchanges and laundered money for ransomware gangs
desc: Gang is believed to have laundered more than $42 million in criminal proceeds.

title: Some email clients are vulnerable to attacks via 'mailto' links
desc: GNOME Evolution, KDE KMail, IBM/HCL Notes, and older versions of Thunderbird found to be vulnerable.

title: Facebook forcing Oculus users to have an account on its platform
desc: Oculus mandates Facebook account for VR log in from beginning of October.

title: Former PM Turnbull suggests Australia boosts its cyber capability by buying local
desc: Former prime minister said there is a need to be a 'megaphone' for domestic capabilities and for large organisations and agencies to stop simply buying from the tech giants.

title: Critical Jenkins Server Vulnerability Could Leak Sensitive Information
desc: Jenkins—a popular open-source automation server software—published an advisory  on Monday concerning a critical vulnerability in the Jetty web server that could result in memory corruption and cause confidential information to be disclosed.

title: How AppTrana Managed Cloud WAF Tackles Evolving Attacking Techniques
desc: Web applications suffer continuously evolving attacks, where a web application firewall (WAF) is the first line of defense and a necessary part of organizations' cybersecurity strategies.

title: Researchers Exploited A Bug in Emotet to Stop the Spread of Malware
desc: Emotet, a notorious email-based malware behind several botnet-driven spam campaigns and ransomware attacks, contained a flaw that allowed cybersecurity researchers to activate a kill-switch and prevent the malware from infecting systems for six months.

title: US regulators settle with CenturyLink over anti-competition violations
desc: CenturyLink allegedly flouted court orders designed to stop anti-competitive behavior linked to the merger with Level 3.

title: Controversial facial recognition tech firm Clearview AI inks deal with ICE
desc: $224,000 has been spent on Clearview licenses by the US immigration and customs department.

title: Ritz London suspects data breach, fraudsters pose as staff in credit card data scam
desc: Scammers phoned guests to “confirm” their credit card details for reservations.

title: Huawei ban expanded to include foreign-made chips using US tech
desc: US government says its move to restrict the Chinese tech giant from accessing chips made by foreign manufacturers using US technology aims to "impede" Huawei's attempts to circumvent earlier controls by going through third parties.

title: Crypto-mining worm steal AWS credentials
desc: TeamTNT has become the first crypto-minining botnet to include a feature that scans and steal AWS credentials.

title: There’s a growing blind spot for your security team during the pandemic: IoT devices
desc: Businesses may not be able to dictate what devices employees keep on their home networks, there are still many options available to IT departments to protect company assets.

title: Who is responsible for responsible AI?
desc: Accountability in AI is a tricky topic. The key is for companies to build and deploy responsible AI systems from the get go, to minimize overall risk, preempt your AI system from performing in an illegal, unethical, or unintended way.

title: Microsoft's Control Flow Guard comes to Rust and LLVM compilers
desc: This is the first step towards Chrome and Edge getting Windows CFG support.

title: World's largest cruise line operator discloses ransomware attack
desc: Carnival Corp says it suffered a ransomware attack on Saturday, August 15, and that hackers stole some of its data.

title: Chrome for Android to label 'Fast page' sites as Google clamps down on mixed forms
desc: Google to hand out new label based on its own metrics.

title: US Army report says many North Korean hackers operate from abroad
desc: US Army says many North Korean hackers are actually located outside the hermit kingdom, in countries like Belarus, China, India, Malaysia, and Russia.

title: APAC consumers believe onus on businesses, governments to safeguard their data
desc: Almost 70% of consumers in Asia-Pacific will give up their privacy for better user experience, but just 25% feel they're responsible for protecting their own data, with the rest of pushing this role to governments and organisations.

title: NHS hit with wave of scam emails at height of COVID-19 pandemic
desc: NHS Digital said its cybersecurity teams were working hard to keep patient data secure as attackers continued to target under-pressure services.

title: Re­VoL­TE attack can decrypt 4G (LTE) calls to eavesdrop on conversations
desc: Academics detail a new attack on 4G encrypted calls. Attack works only when the attacker is on the same base station (mobile tower) as the victim.

title: RedCurl cybercrime group has hacked companies for three years
desc: New stealthy Russian-speaking hacker group discovered.

title: FireEye’s bug bounty program goes public
desc: 42 vulnerabilities in FireEye domains have, so far, been resolved.

title: In one click: Amazon Alexa could be exploited for theft of voice history, PII, skill tampering
desc: Subdomains belonging to the service were found to be harboring CORS errors and vulnerable to XSS attacks.

title: Signal adds message requests to stop spam and protect user privacy
desc: New feature lets Signal users control who can text or voice call, add them to groups.

title: Google: We'll test hiding the full URL in Chrome 86 to combat phishing
desc: Google aims to find out if showing only a domain name in the address bar will help Chrome users spot scams.

title: FBI and NSA expose new Linux malware Drovorub, used by Russian state hackers
desc: The FBI and NSA issue joint security alert containing technical details about new Linux malware developed by Russia's military hackers.

title: 300,000 links taken down in crackdown on investment scams with bogus celebrity endorsements
desc: NCSC issues warning to criminals stealing money from people with the promise of get-rich-quick schemes from phoney celebrity testimonials that cost victims hundreds of millions a year.

title: A simple telephony honeypot received 1.5 million robocalls across 11 months
desc: Researchers say that most campaigns take place in short-burst storms and that answering a robocall doesn't mean you'll be targeted more often in the future.

title: CactusPete hackers go on European rampage with Bisonal backdoor upgrade
desc: The APT is attacking banks and military organizations in Eastern Europe.

title: Mac malware spreads through Xcode projects, abuses WebKit, Data Vault vulnerabilities
desc: XCSSET malware focuses on exploiting Safari and other browsers.

title: For six months, security researchers have secretly distributed an Emotet vaccine across the world
desc: Binary Defense researchers have identified a bug in the Emotet malware and have been using it to prevent the malware from making new victims.

title: This surprise Linux malware warning shows that hackers are changing their targets
desc: The old assumptions about security are wrong and will need updating, fast.

title: A New vBulletin 0-Day RCE Vulnerability and Exploit Disclosed Publicly
desc: A security researcher earlier today publicly revealed details and proof-of-concept exploit code for an unpatched, critical zero-day remote code execution vulnerability affecting the widely used internet forum software vBulletin  that's already under active exploitation in the wild.

title: Google Chrome Bug Could Let Hackers Bypass CSP Protection; Update Web Browsers
desc: If you haven't recently updated your Chrome, Opera, or Edge web browser to the latest available version, it would be an excellent idea to do so as quickly as possible.

title: Critical Flaws Affect Citrix Endpoint Management (XenMobile Servers)
desc: Citrix today released patches for multiple new security vulnerabilities affecting its Citrix Endpoint Management (CEM) , also known as XenMobile, a product made for enterprises to help companies manage and secure their employees' mobile devices remotely.

title: Contrast Community Edition Empowers Developers to Write Secure Code Faster
desc: As software eats the world, the world faces a software security crisis. The movement to modern software such as cloud technologies and microservice architectures is essential to innovate quickly. Yet, nearly three in four developers say that security slows down Agile and DevOps.

title: Flaws in Samsung Phones Exposed Android Users to Remote Attacks
desc: New research disclosed a string of severe security vulnerabilities in the ' Find My Mobile '—an Android app that comes pre-installed on most Samsung smartphones—that could have allowed remote attackers to track victims' real-time location, monitor phone calls, and messages, and even delete data stor...

title: Microsoft Reveals New Innocent Ways Windows Users Can Get Hacked
desc: Microsoft earlier today released its August 2020 batch of software security updates for all supported versions of its Windows operating systems and other products.

title: Amazon Alexa Bugs Allowed Hackers to Install Malicious Skills Remotely
desc: Attention! If you use Amazon's voice assistant Alexa in you smart speakers, just opening an innocent-looking web-link could let attackers install hacking skills on it and spy on your activities remotely.

title: New Attack Lets Hackers Decrypt VoLTE Encryption to Spy on Phone Calls
desc: A team of academic researchers—who previously made the headlines earlier this year for uncovering severe security issues in the 4G LTE and 5G networks —today presented a new attack called ' ReVoLTE ,' that could let remote attackers break the encryption used by VoLTE voice calls and spy on targeted ...
